metadata.titleEn: Landuse/Landcover data of the Heihe river basin (2000)
metadata.description:
China 1:100000 data of land use is a major application in the Chinese Academy of Sciences "five-year" project "the national resources and environment remote sensing macroscopic investigation and study of dynamic organized 19 Chinese Academy of Sciences institute of remote sensing science and technology team, by means of satellite remote sensing, in three years based on Landsat MSS, TM and ETM remote sensing data established China 1:100000 images and vector of land use database.The main contents include: China 1:100,000 land use data;China 1:100,000 land use graph data and attribute data.
The data was directly clipped from China's 1:100,000 land-use data.A hierarchical land cover classification system was adopted for the land use data of heihe basin of 1:100,000, and the whole basin was divided into 6 primary categories (arable land, forest land, grassland, water area, urban and rural areas, industrial and mining areas, residential land and unused land) and 26 secondary categories.The data type is vector polygon, which is stored in Shape format.There are two types of data projection: WGS84/ALBERS;Data coverage covers the new heihe watershed boundary (lack of outer Mongolia data).
Land use classification attributes:
The first class type and the second class type attributes encode the spatial distribution position
Cultivated paddy field 113 is mainly distributed in alluvial plain, basin and valley
Cultivated paddy field 112 distributed in hilly valley narrow valley platform or beach (with irrigation conditions)
Cultivated paddy field 111 is mainly distributed in mountain valley narrow valley platform or beach (with better irrigation conditions)
Arable land 124 is mainly distributed in mountainous areas, the slope is generally more than 25 degrees (belongs to the steep slope hanging land), should be returned to forest.
Cultivated dry land 123 is mainly distributed in basins, piedmont belts, river alluvial, diluvial or lacustrine plains (water shortage and poor irrigation conditions).
Cultivated dry land 122 is mainly distributed in hilly areas (shaanxi, gan, ning, qing).In general, the plot is distributed on gentle slopes and x and sockets of hills.
Arable land 121 is mainly distributed in the mountainous area, with an elevation of 4000 meters below the slope (gentle slope, mountainside, steep slope platform, etc.) and mountain front belt.
Woodlands have woodlands (trees) 21 mainly distributed in the mountains (below 4000 meters above sea level) or in the slope, valley two slopes, mountain tops, plains.In qinghai nanshan, qilian mountains are.
Woodland shrub 22 is mainly distributed in the higher mountain areas (below 4500 m), most of the distribution of hillside and valley and sand.
Forest dredging 23 mainly distributed in the mountains, hills, plains and sandy land, gobi (soil, gravel) edge.
Other woodlands 24 are mainly distributed in the oasis ridge, river, roadside and rural residential areas around.
Grassland 31 is generally distributed in mountainous areas (gentle slopes), hills (steep slopes) and interriver beaches, gobi desert, sandy hills, etc.
The covered grassland 32 is mainly distributed in dry places (next door low-lying land and sandy hills, etc.).
Grassland low cover grassland 33 mainly grows in drier places (loess hills and sandy edges).
The river channel 41 is mainly distributed in the plain, the cultivated land between the rivers and the valleys in the mountains.
Water lakes are mainly distributed in low-lying areas.
The reservoirs are mainly distributed in the intermountain lowlands and intersandy hills in qinghai province.
Water area glaciers and permanent snow 44 mainly distributed in the plain, the valley between the river, there are surrounding residents and arable land.
Waters and beaches are mainly distributed on the top of (over 4000) mountains.
metadata.instructions:
File name: data is stored in vector SHP format, file name "heihe_landuse_2000.shp".
Data reading: Arcgis, Qgis and other remote sensing software can be used to open and read.

background: Land-use/cover change has become an event being of paramount importance to the study of global environmental change. Land-cover change is closely related to the terrestrial surface material cycles and life-support processes, i.e., the interaction between biosphere and atmosphere, biodiversity, biogeochemical cycle and sustainable exploitation of resources. The series of scientific study programs, issued and promoted by IGBP and IHDP in 1995, make the study of land-use and land-cover change (LUCC) become one of the hot topics in the global environmental change study. As a developing but booming country, China has formulated a series of policies exerting great influence on the land-use change. In addition, due to varied physical environments and vast land areas, its land-use changes not only influence the social and economic development but also impact the global change accordingly.
research objective: In this paper, the division of dynamic regionalization of land-use change is designed, for the sake of revealing the temporal and spatial features of land-use change and laying the foundation for the study of regional scale land-use changes. The paper exerts an effective effort on the integrated studies of “spatial pattern” and “temporal process” for land-use change to reveal the regional land-use change characteristics on the pattern of dynamic process and dynamic process of pattern.
challenges: It is too early to say that the trend of deforestation has been effectively reversed across China. There also exist conspicuous conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion, as showed in the irrational conversion from arable land to built-up areas.
dataset: The main data sources are Landsat TM digital images (520 scenes in 1995/1996 and 508 scenes in 1999/2000). Apart from that, the CBERS-1 (China-Brazil Earth Resources Satellite 1) data were also used to acquire land-use information for 1999/2000.
findings: There exists conspicuous regional differentiation of land-use change in China, which lays the foundation to draw the dynamic zones. The rapid change of land-use change during 1995—2000 happened in North China, Loess Plateau—agricultural and pasturing interlaced area, Northeast China, southeast coastal region, middle and lower reaches of Yangtze River, eastern coastal region.

Concept Completion.Answer: river alluvial plains, basins, valleys, mountain slopes, hilly areas

Concept Completion.Answer: Conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how satellite remote sensing technology is utilized to create a land-use/land-cover dataset for a specific region?
Example.Answer: The 黑河流域土地利用/土地覆盖数据集（2000） is an example where satellite remote sensing technology, specifically using Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM data, was utilized to create a land-use/land-cover dataset for the Heihe River Basin at a scale of 1:100,000.

Example.Question: What is an example of a classification system used in land-use/land-cover data collection, and how does it organize the data?
Example.Answer: An example of a classification system is the one used in the 黑河流域土地利用/土地覆盖数据集（2000）, which organizes the land-use data into a layered system with six primary categories such as arable land, forest land, grassland, water areas, urban and rural areas, and unused land, further divided into 26 secondary categories.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a challenge faced when balancing land-use changes, such as urban expansion and arable land protection, in environmental research?
Example.Answer: A challenge in balancing land-use changes is exemplified by the conspicuous conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion in China, where there is an irrational conversion from arable land to built-up areas, as noted in the research on land-use change dynamics.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific features of the land-use classification system used for the Heihe River Basin dataset?
Feature Specification.Answer: hierarchical, six primary categories, 26 secondary categories, vector polygon data, Shape format, WGS84/ALBERS projections, new Heihe River Basin boundary

Feature Specification.Answer: regional differentiation of land-use changes, conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion, accurately capturing temporal and spatial features, complexity of varied physical environments and policies

Definition.Question: What does 'land-use/cover change' refer to in the context of global environmental change studies?
Definition.Answer: Land-use/cover change refers to the alterations in the terrestrial surface material cycles and life-support processes, such as the interaction between biosphere and atmosphere, biodiversity, biogeochemical cycle, and sustainable exploitation of resources. It is a critical aspect of global environmental change studies, with significant implications for both local and global scales, especially in the context of a developing country like China.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using a 'dynamic regionalization of land-use change' in environmental studies?
Definition.Answer: Dynamic regionalization of land-use change is significant as it helps in revealing the temporal and spatial features of land-use change. This concept lays the foundation for studying regional-scale land-use changes by integrating spatial patterns and temporal processes to understand the dynamic process of pattern and pattern of dynamic processes in land-use changes.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection methods between using Landsat TM digital images and CBERS-1 data for land-use and land-cover information?
Comparison.Answer: Landsat TM digital images and CBERS-1 data both serve as primary data sources, but they might differ in spectral resolution, revisit times, and data processing techniques. While both provide land-use information, their integration could offer complementary insights into land-use changes across different times and spatial resolutions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately classifying land-use types in the Heihe River Basin using satellite imagery?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges include the varied physical environments and vast land areas of China, which lead to conspicuous regional differentiation of land-use change. This regional differentiation could complicate the classification process, especially in areas where there are conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are there significant challenges associated with balancing arable land protection and urban expansion in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges stem from conspicuous conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion, as evidenced by the irrational conversion from arable land to built-up areas. These land-use changes are influenced by China's development policies and the varied physical environments across the country.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes regional differentiation in land-use change across China, and how does it impact data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Regional differentiation of land-use change is caused by China's diverse physical environments and vast land areas, which affect both social and economic development and global change. This differentiation impacts data collection methods by necessitating tailored approaches to capture the unique land-use changes in different regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using a layered land cover classification system on the accuracy and detail of land-use data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a layered land cover classification system allows for more detailed categorization of land-use types, which can result in increased accuracy and specificity of data, enabling better analysis of spatial patterns and temporal processes of land-use changes.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the integration of various satellite data sources impact the interpretation of land-use changes over time?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating various satellite data sources, such as Landsat and CBERS-1, can provide a more comprehensive dataset that enhances the ability to track and interpret land-use changes over time, potentially leading to more robust findings on regional differentiation and dynamic zones of change.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of developing a land-use/land-cover dataset for the Heihe River Basin using satellite remote sensing data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to establish a comprehensive and detailed land-use/land-cover database for the Heihe River Basin, which serves as a foundation for understanding spatial and temporal features of land-use change. This aids in the study of regional scale land-use changes and supports the broader investigation of global environmental change impacts.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to employ a hierarchical land cover classification system in the creation of a land-use dataset for the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Utilizing a hierarchical land cover classification system is crucial for distinguishing various land-use types at different levels of detail, which allows for a more nuanced understanding of land-use dynamics and their spatial distribution. This classification helps in accurately categorizing the land into primary and secondary types, facilitating detailed analysis and policy formulation.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended goals behind integrating data from multiple satellite sources, such as Landsat and CBERS-1, in land-use research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The integration of data from multiple satellite sources like Landsat and CBERS-1 aims to enhance the accuracy and comprehensiveness of land-use information by utilizing varied spectral, spatial, and temporal resolutions. This approach supports the detection of land-use changes over time and improves the reliability of dynamic regionalization and temporal analysis of land-use patterns.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to integrate satellite remote sensing data, like Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM, into a cohesive land-use/cover classification system for a specific region?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The integration of satellite remote sensing data into a land-use/cover classification system involves organizing a team of researchers across various institutes, using satellite data to establish detailed land-use imagery and vector databases. This is achieved by employing a layered land-cover classification system that categorizes the region into primary and secondary classes, such as farmland, forest, grassland, water bodies, urban areas, industrial/mining zones, and unused land.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can regional differentiation of land-use change be identified using satellite images and other Earth observation data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Regional differentiation of land-use change can be identified by analyzing digital images from sources like Landsat TM and CBERS-1. These images help reveal dynamic zones and rapid changes in specific areas by examining temporal and spatial land-use patterns, as evidenced by changes in regions such as North China and the Loess Plateau.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the creation of a comprehensive land-use/land-cover database using satellite imagery?
Enablement.Answer: The creation of a comprehensive land-use/land-cover database using satellite imagery is enabled by advancements in satellite remote sensing technologies, specifically the use of Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM data, which provide high-resolution digital images for detailed analysis of land-use patterns.

Enablement.Question: How do methodological approaches in land-use classification systems enable accurate representation of diverse land categories?
Enablement.Answer: Methodological approaches in land-use classification systems, such as the use of a hierarchical classification system with multiple levels of categories, enable accurate representation of diverse land categories by allowing detailed differentiation among types such as cultivated land, forest land, grassland, water bodies, urban areas, and unused land.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the integration of multi-temporal satellite data enable the analysis of dynamic land-use changes over time?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of multi-temporal satellite data, such as Landsat TM images from different years, enables the analysis of dynamic land-use changes over time by providing consistent and comparable datasets that reveal temporal and spatial features of land-use changes, facilitating regional scale studies.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in accurately classifying land-use types using satellite imagery in diverse geographical regions?
Expectation.Answer: There exists conspicuous regional differentiation of land-use change in China, which lays the foundation to draw the dynamic zones. This differentiation, along with varied physical environments and vast land areas, poses challenges for accurate classification using satellite imagery.

Expectation.Question: Why might some regions face greater challenges in reversing deforestation trends despite the availability of remote sensing data?
Expectation.Answer: It is too early to say that the trend of deforestation has been effectively reversed across China. Conspicuous conflicts exist between arable land protection and urban expansion, as shown in the irrational conversion from arable land to built-up areas, which may hinder efforts to reverse deforestation trends.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of using a layered land cover classification system in capturing detailed spatial patterns of land use change in large catchment areas like the Heihe River Basin?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of a layered land cover classification system, which divides the region into primary and secondary categories, appears to be highly effective in capturing detailed spatial patterns of land use change. This system allows for a nuanced understanding of land use dynamics across different terrains and altitudes, as demonstrated in the Heihe River Basin data collection, which categorizes land use into specific types such as irrigated and non-irrigated farmland, forested areas, and urban expansion.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the challenges faced in balancing the need for land conservation with urban expansion, particularly with regard to land use data collected through remote sensing methods like Landsat and CBERS-1?
Judgmental.Answer: Balancing land conservation with urban expansion presents significant challenges, as there are often competing interests between preserving arable land and accommodating urban growth. Remote sensing methods, such as those using Landsat and CBERS-1, provide valuable data on land use changes, allowing researchers to identify areas where these conflicts are most pronounced. However, the data also highlight ongoing issues, such as the continued conversion of farmland to urban areas, suggesting that further policy interventions and strategic planning are needed to address these conflicts effectively.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how different satellite data sources are integrated to form a comprehensive land-use database.
Assertion.Answer: The main data sources for a comprehensive land-use database include Landsat TM digital images and CBERS-1 data, which are used to acquire land-use information. These datasets provide a basis for creating a detailed land-use/land-cover map, including the integration of temporal and spatial features of land-use change.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the classification system for land-use types is structured to ensure accuracy across diverse regions.
Assertion.Answer: The land-use classification system is structured in a hierarchical manner with six primary categories and twenty-six secondary categories. This system allows for detailed categorization and spatial distribution representation, ensuring that different terrains and land-use conditions are accurately represented in the dataset.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges that arise when attempting to balance urban expansion and arable land protection using land-use data.
Assertion.Answer: A significant challenge is the conflict between arable land protection and urban expansion, as there is often irrational conversion from arable land to built-up areas. This issue highlights the need for careful policy formulation and land-use planning to address these conflicts.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in balancing arable land protection with urban expansion in the context of land-use change in China.
Request/Directive.Answer: Balancing arable land protection with urban expansion in China involves addressing conspicuous conflicts, as there is an irrational conversion from arable land to built-up areas. This challenge is heightened by the need to reverse deforestation trends and manage land-use changes that are influenced by both economic development and environmental sustainability.
